pr_comments.body:
Sorry, it's been a while since I did LSP stuff, but I start to remember again.

https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/lsp/3.18/specification/#workspace_textDocumentContent

This allows the server to provide documents with virtual URIs that then can be opened by the client (VS Code).

- Your `Definition.uri` will be something like `html-server://typescript-libs/lib.d.ts`.
- In the client you declare that the server can provide document contents for schema `html-server`
- In the server you have a provider that serves these documents using the `libs.loadLibrary(`lib.d.ts') call.

What do you think? I think that's the right approach, which will also work on vscode.dev.
pr_comments.author: aeschli

pr_comments.body:
> Sorry, it's been a while since I did LSP stuff, but I start to remember again.
> 
> https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/lsp/3.18/specification/#workspace_textDocumentContent
> 
> This allows the server to provide documents with virtual URIs that then can be opened by the client (VS Code).
> 
> * Your `Definition.uri` will be something like `html-server://typescript-libs/lib.d.ts`.
> * In the client you declare that the server can provide document contents for schema `html-server`
> * In the server you have a provider that serves these documents using the `libs.loadLibrary(`lib.d.ts') call.
> 
> What do you think? I think that's the right approach, which will also work on vscode.dev.

I think that's a good approach, but I want to clarify a few things before I work on the new approach.

1. Currently, I am testing out the web version by running `npm run watch`, then `npm run watch-web` and `.\scripts\code-web`. On browser, it shows the definition as expected.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3c8046b2-58d3-4b9e-9fd6-665da1b08ba1)

Are there other things I am missing that makes it not compatible on vscode.dev?

2. In client, I am not too sure where the server capabilities are declared. Is it just in the `clientOptions.initializationOptions`?
pr_comments.author: nknguyenhc
aeschli

pr_comments.body:
@aeschli I have implemented the new endpoint in the server to serve file content. But one downside to it is that upon opening the definition file, the file header does not show.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7b660f12-b098-42b1-80cd-b5c736950fb1)

In contrast to `typescript-language-features`, upon opening the definition file, the file header shows.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a26223d3-a371-470c-b52c-f6ec147853e6)

The behaviour is the same both on web and on desktop. For desktop, upon reloading the window, the file is no longer displayed.

I'm not sure if this behaviour can be easily fixed, as the `html-language-features` extension is only activated upon html (or handlebars) files are opened. If it is not, the window should not be able to open a file with protocol `html-server:`
pr_comments.author: nknguyenhc

pr_comments.body:
You mean the breadcrumbs. Don't know why they don't show, you have to debug in the breadcrumb code.
For the second issue, Maybe it helps if the json extension has a `"onFileSystem:html-server" activation event?
pr_comments.author: aeschli

pr_comments.body:
@aeschli Here's what I found:

For breadcrumb to be displayed with files from `html-server` scheme, a file system provider needs to be declared in the extension, eg:

```ts
vscode.workspace.registerFileSystemProvider('html-server', /* some file system provider */);
```

However, for a client-server extension like `html-language-features`, the language server protocol is not yet able to handle virtual resources. It is still an open issue in [microsoft/language-server-protocol#1264](https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol/issues/1264). Which means, the client needs to declare the file system provider as above.

For now, I believe the solution is to declare the file system provider as above in the client, and then within the provider, make a call to the server to fetch the file content via `workspace/textDocumentContent`.

What do you think? Lmk how I should proceed.
pr_comments.author: nknguyenhc

pr_comments.body:
Thanks for the analysis!

I see, the LSP client uses the 'TextDocumentContentProvider' to serve the document, not a file system provider. https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/df05883f34b39255d40d68cef55caf2e93cff35f/client/src/common/textDocumentContent.ts#L86

I guess we could file an issue against the LSP client to use a file system provider instead. @dbaeumer FYI. That would help other languages as well that use TextDocumentContents (I believe Java)
https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol/issues/1264 is a different topic, not related to TextDocumentContents

I don't know what happens if there's both a vscode.TextDocumentContentProvider as well as a FileSystemProvider.
I would not try to work around the LSP client. IMO not having the breadcrumbs is a minor issue.
pr_comments.author: aeschli
nknguyenhc

pr_comments.body: @aeschli Other than these 2 issues, the PR is ready to be reviewed.
pr_comments.author: nknguyenhc

@nknguyenhc Very nice and slick! Thanks a lot!

I allowed myself to do a change on the signature of `getTextDocumentContent`. Hope you like it.

pr_comments.body:
To compute the library location, add a new function to https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/91e6ae971de19ccfb32e90f064cf194d81a29a39/extensions/html-language-features/server/src/modes/javascriptLibs.ts#L11 and reuse the logic there.

As for the document URI, this is trickier as this also needs to run on the web (vscode.dev), and there's no 'file' there.
You probably need to start from the [extensionUri](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/91e6ae971de19ccfb32e90f064cf194d81a29a39/src/vscode-dts/vscode.d.ts#L8269) that you get on the HTML client, and pass it on the server.
pr_comments.author: aeschli

pr_comments.body: @aeschli Currently I put the logic here instead of in `javascriptLibs.ts` because webpack (for vscode.dev) uses a different version for it, as specified in `html-language-features/server/extension-browser.webpack.config.js`. Should I declare this logic in `javascriptLibs.ts` and edit the file `html-language-features/server/build/javaScriptLibraryLoader.js` as well, or should I just keep the logic here?
pr_comments.author: nknguyenhc

pr_comments.body: Oh, now I remember, for vscode.dev we just bundle the library files.

data.title: Allow use of custom menu with native titlebar (on Linux and Windows)
data.description:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

Closes #229053

Notes:

- This is my first pull request to VS Code. I've followed all the guidelines I could see, please let me know if I've missed anything.
- I've tested this pretty exhaustively: different combinations of the new "Force Custom Menu Style" setting, the existing "Title Bar Style" and "Menu Bar Visibility" settings, and whether or not the Command Center and/or Layout Controls are hidden, on Debian 12 (with [MATE](https://mate-desktop.org/), which is my primary desktop environment) and Windows 11. I tested going in and out of fullscreen, and pressing Alt or Alt-F, with these different combinations, as these all affect showing/hiding the menu.
- I cannot test on Mac as I don't have a Mac. I also cannot test on Web as trying to run `npm run watch-web` gives me a glorious out-of-memory error. Those platforms should not see any change at all, so hopefully this doesn't introduce any regressions to them, but someone who can will need to check them.
- I made it so that the new "Force Custom Menu Style" setting requires a restart to take effect, in the same way as the "Title Bar Style" setting. See below.

**Side-track: Why does the new setting require a restart?**

At first, I did try to make it so that it didn't require a restart, but this sent me down a rabbit hole of a fair bit of refactoring (which would make it a lot harder to review if I included that!) as well as at least two bugs I couldn't figure out causing oddities when certain things are changed on the fly. These bugs already existed in unchanged VS Code, at least in v1.91.1 where I started developing this before rebasing, and can be reproduced if you try hard enough, by following certain steps including changing settings, saying "cancel" to the restart prompt and then changing more settings. So, I don't want that to hold up getting this pull request in, and I'm not going to be spending any more time on this (nor do I think it's worth me raising an issue for) if no one else is interested in sorting this out, but if anyone is looking at this area already, please link an appropriate issue and I can certainly share my findings in more detail there.

pr_comments.body: @microsoft-github-policy-service agree
pr_comments.author: tycode

pr_comments.body:
Hi @sbatten @benibenj

It's been nearly two months.

#224515 is still open with 70 thumbs-up (meaning countless more people will be out there with this issue who have _not_ indicated this) and so far I haven't seen any alternative solution proposed. I personally am stuck on VS Code 1.91.x because of this, and I don't want to be getting further and further behind forever.

Could someone please let me know if there is any chance this feature will be adopted, or if the team is working on an alternative resolution?

I'm happy to rebase this to a newer VS Code version, resolve conflicts and re-test, if that would help get this merged, but I'd appreciate some indication that that effort would not go to waste first.
pr_comments.author: tycode

pr_comments.body:
@tycode Sorry about the longer wait. We are evaluating how likely it is that this will be fixed upstream in a reasonable time frame. We do not want to introduce a new setting just for a couple months if it will be fixed. If we can tell that this will be a long standing problem then we will consider addressing the issue with this PR.

Currently the workaround is to use the custom title bar.
pr_comments.author: benibenj
tycode

pr_comments.body:
Electron ("upstream") confirmed their position - they won't carry patches to restore native menus on their end:

* https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/42262#issuecomment-2544981851

Considering the general consensus from the comments, it _seems very unlikely_ that their upstream (Chromium) will address this any time soon.

I hope the Electron API docs can clarify that native != Chromium menus.

* https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/45033

---

I agree that separating the options would be a good move. VS Code's custom menus are much better, but the native title bar is essential for me. With some window manager magic (in KDE), I can have both, and this PR will help me eliminate 'double window controls' that I've introduced onto myself:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/203ef261-9849-4e57-9732-7f1e771c839c)

[_(See other comment)_](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/224515#issuecomment-2545724749) | It'll also help when maximized, since my cursor near the far edge (for activity bar) starts clicking/dragging like it was the window border.

Thank you both for looking into it!
pr_comments.author: lah7

pr_comments.body:
Hi @benibenj

As it is now three and a half months later - and, as @lah7 mentioned above, it looks like there is no chance of the original issue being resolved upstream - I just wanted to check in and see if there is any desire within the VS Code team yet to see this PR merged - or something else similar that would achieve the same goal.

I appreciate that my PR is now even more outdated and will need updating and re-testing. I am still happy to do this if there is a reasonable prospect it will be merged.

Alternatively - if you have a proposal for a better UX (or a more maintainable solution) than a "Force Custom Menu Style" setting as here - I'd be happy to implement whatever, as long as it achieves the goal (providing the ability to use the custom menu style with the native title bar) and isn't unreasonable.
pr_comments.author: tycode
benibenj

pr_comments.body:
@benibenj 

> I’ve created a new PR that introduces a window.menuStyle setting, which can be set to native, custom, or inherit (the latter following the style of the title bar).

Thanks! This is great news. I've done a quick test of the latest Insiders release (1.101.0-1747983231, 747d0bd66a4699a53e720cf7a61dcd10f664e667) and raised the two small issues I could see, hopefully they should be fairly simple to fix:

- #249745
- #249746

Having these sorted in the next Stable release would be ideal, and should allow me to upgrade again at last.

As an aside, I'm pleased with the way the new `menuStyle` setting is laid out - it feels better worded than my "force custom" setting, and the "native" option (which at the moment seems like it'll always do the same as "inherit") seems good future proofing for if that combination becomes available, which my setting didn't provide for.

> [The new PR] was very much inspired by your work, and I’d be happy to add you as a co-author if you’d like.

Feel free to! I don't really mind whether I'm attributed here or not, to be honest - what's important is having this functionality in! :)
pr_comments.author: tycode

data.title: ci: remove explicit dbus setup
data.description:
For unknown reasons the dbus setup is breaking docker container runs with the following error, this is a blocker for unifying snap job with the linux job.

```
docker: Error response from daemon: failed to create task for container: failed to create shim task: OCI runtime create failed: runc create failed: unable to start container process: unable to apply cgroup configuration: unable to start unit
```

Removing the dbus setup results in the following errors but tests are passing without issues, lets revisit if these errors interfere with the tests.

```
[19611:0409/145730.028508:ERROR:bus.cc(407)] Failed to connect to the bus: Could not parse server address: Unknown address type (examples of valid types are "tcp" and on UNIX "unix")
[19611:0409/145730.028563:ERROR:bus.cc(407)] Failed to connect to the bus: Could not parse server address: Unknown address type (examples of valid types are "tcp" and on UNIX "unix")
[19611:0409/145730.028586:ERROR:bus.cc(407)] Failed to connect to the bus: Could not parse server address: Unknown address type (examples of valid types are "tcp" and on UNIX "unix")
[19611:0409/145730.028594:ERROR:bus.cc(407)] Failed to connect to the bus: Could not parse server address: Unknown address type (examples of valid types are "tcp" and on UNIX "unix")
[19611:0409/145730.028603:ERROR:object_proxy.cc(576)] Failed to call method: org.freedesktop.DBus.NameHasOwner: object_path= /org/freedesktop/DBus: unknown error type: 
[19611:0409/145730.049019:ERROR:bus.cc(407)] Failed to connect to the bus: Could not parse server address: Unknown address type (examples of valid types are "tcp" and on UNIX "unix")
```

If the `parsedCell` is invalid, then doesn't this mean the cell no longer exists?
Also shouldn't we then just return `undefined `here, instead of returning something invalid by making up the details, as that could lead to other issues.

2fe66fbd482265c2fad582fa9897a6e02c4ad874.commit_message:
Fix scheme mixup in FileSystemWatcher

In FileSystemWatcher, if a "created" event fired for

  `tmpfs:///project/`

It would fire the event for files sharing the same prefix but different scheme. In our case:

  `memfs:///project/package.json`

This caused an assertion in typescript-language-features breaking intellisense.

I also added a new test but it doesn't test this particular fix.
2fe66fbd482265c2fad582fa9897a6e02c4ad874.author: Juan Campa

e77d9e03c917a2de36f15541741c8c17a0870e20.commit_message:
Rip out terminals from VSCode (#3)

* Disable terminal functionality

I removed most of the terminal-related contributions (terminal.contribution.ts), which includes: commands, the terminal tab, menu items, keybindings, and so on.

Many terminal-related services are used by other services (e.g. the task service depends on the terminal service), so removing TerminalService would cause a cascade of "missing singleton" errors.

Thankfully vscode uses DI everywhere,  so I replaced the TerminalService with our own empty shell of a service. Same for a few related services. The empty shells are there to satisfy the dependency injection system.

Note that there's still quite a bit of terminal-related code left that I think will end up in our build. We might be able to use a webpack plugin to for example, replace xterm.js with a dummy module.

* Undo extension webpack change
e77d9e03c917a2de36f15541741c8c17a0870e20.author: Juan Campa

pr_comments.body:
the failing check is Code - OSS

```
[eslint                   ] [13:41:36] /mnt/vss/_work/1/s/src/vs/workbench/services/configurationResolver/common/configurationResolverExpression.ts: line 227, col 40, Warning - Missing semicolon. (@stylistic/ts/semi)
[eslint                   ] /mnt/vss/_work/1/s/src/vs/workbench/services/configurationResolver/common/configurationResolverExpression.ts: line 229, col 33, Warning - Missing semicolon. (@stylistic/ts/semi)
[eslint                   ] /mnt/vss/_work/1/s/src/vs/workbench/services/configurationResolver/common/configurationResolverExpression.ts: line 230, col 30, Warning - Missing semicolon. (@stylistic/ts/semi)
```

and a test failure on Linux/macOS

```
1) Configuration Resolver Service
       substitution in object key:

      
      + expected - actual

       {
         "mappings": {
      -    "/VSCode/workspaceLocation/test1": "/VSCode/workspaceLocation/test2"
      +    "file:///VSCode/workspaceLocation/test1": "file:///VSCode/workspaceLocation/test2"
           "pos1": "value1"
           "pos3": "value3"
         }
```

data.author: mahmoudsalah1993

data.title: add manage custom chat modes command
data.description:
FYI @roblourens @legomushroom @digitarald

This adds new commands 
- New Custom Chat Mode
- Manage Custom Chat Modes

Based on my thinking that prompt files and mode files are not exactly the same (see https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot/issues/17638#issuecomment-2900355023), I decided to start with a new file extension `.chatmode.md`.

- A prompt file represents a chat request and consists of a user query, tool selection and context (files, rules (aka instructions, The prompt file body consists of the user query that also lists context (via # and md-links). 
- A mode file has selected tools and contexts but no user query. 
The prompt file body defines additional context via # and md-links. 

Using separate file extensions has the following advantages:
- allows the user to place prompt files and mode files in the same folder
- customize editing support for prompt files and mode files
- looking at the file name is enough to know what the file was designed for

I'm happy to discuss this and change this. 

There's also a new setting 'chat.modeFilesLocations'.

For @roblourens there API to access modes:

`IPromptsService.getCustomChatModes` and `IPromptsService.onDidChangeCustomChatModes`


Still TODO:
- Make labels consistent, Right now it mostly uses 'Custom Change Mode', but not everywhere
- onDidChangeCustomChatModes not implemented
- editor is not yet aware of the new mode. No mode specific validation, code assist, etc.

data.author: bpasero

data.title: Add shortcuts to compare incoming/current with common ancestor
data.description:
Git has a diff style `diff3` or `zdiff3` that shows the common ancestor of two conflicting commits in the conflict. For example:

```
<<<<<<< HEAD
	int c = 2;
||||||| parent of ed293d1 (Capitalise)
	int c;
=======
	int C;
>>>>>>> ed293d1 (Capitalise)
```

This is enormously useful when resolving conflicts. However sometimes git is dumb and you end up with conflicts that are difficult to follow.

For example suppose you have some `really long old code`, and you write some `new code` to replace it. You rebase your change, and find that someone has made a tiny tiny change *somewhere* in the really long old code. It *might* be relevant - it could be some change that you also need to apply to your new code. But the conflict just looks like this:

```
<<<<<<< HEAD
	really
	long
	old
	code
||||||| parent of ed293d1 (Capitalise)
	really
	Long
	old
	code
=======
	new
	code
>>>>>>> ed293d1 (Capitalise)
```

Not too bad with 4 lines but sometimes it's hundreds, and then you end up visually diffing it, like a cave man.

There is an existing `Compare Changes` option, but it only compares `Current` with `Incoming`. This commit adds two more options to compare the common ancestor with `Current` or `Incoming` instead, thus solving the problem once and for all.

This was mostly straightforward. The two tricky bits are:

1. Apparently you can have more than one common ancestor. I've never seen that so I just don't show the buttons in that case (or pick the first common ancestor if you use the command palette).
2. What if you don't have `diff3` and still run the new compare commands from the command palette? In that case it falls back to not showing any changes.

6890dd3029711c0a5ebcf2e1c9d4b3a682fd7a28.commit_message:
Add shortcuts to compare incoming/current with common ancestor

Git has a diff style `diff3` or `zdiff3` that shows the common ancestor of two conflicting commits in the conflict. For example:

```
<<<<<<< HEAD
	int c = 2;
||||||| parent of ed293d1 (Capitalise)
	int c;
=======
	int C;
>>>>>>> ed293d1 (Capitalise)
```

This is enormously useful when resolving conflicts. However sometimes git is dumb and you end up with conflicts that are difficult to follow.

For example suppose you have some `really long old code`, and you write some `new code` to replace it. You rebase your change, and find that someone has made a tiny tiny change *somewhere* in the really long old code. It *might* be relevant - it could be some change that you also need to apply to your new code. But the conflict just looks like this:

```
<<<<<<< HEAD
	really
	long
	old
	code
||||||| parent of ed293d1 (Capitalise)
	really
	Long
	old
	code
=======
	new
	code
>>>>>>> ed293d1 (Capitalise)
```

Not too bad with 4 lines but sometimes it's hundreds, and then you end up visually diffing it, like a cave man.

There is an existing `Compare Changes` option, but it only compares `Current` with `Incoming`. This commit adds two more options to compare the common ancestor with `Current` or `Incoming` instead, thus solving the problem once and for all.

This was mostly straightforward. The two tricky bits are:

1. Apparently you can have more than one common ancestor. I've never seen that so I just don't show the buttons in that case (or pick the first common ancestor if you use the command palette).
2. What if you don't have `diff3` and still run the new compare commands from the command palette? In that case it falls back to not showing any changes.
6890dd3029711c0a5ebcf2e1c9d4b3a682fd7a28.author: Tim Hutt

pr_comments.author: chrmarti

pr_comments.body:
The "Open Merge Editor" button should show for all files that are marked as conflicting by git. The merge editor should cover this feature request.
I think adding these two commands to the code lens might be a bit much. Maybe an extension candidate, since the real merge editor covers this already?
pr_comments.author: hediet

pr_comments.body:
Closing, as I believe this should start with a feature request issue, to get community feedback.
Thanks for the PR nonetheless!
pr_comments.author: hediet

pr_comments.body:
The merge editor doesn't cover this feature. It sort of highlights things that have changed but only like "something happened here" and frankly I just find it confusing and unhelpful.

I'd be happy to do this in an extension but is that actually possible?
pr_comments.author: Timmmm

pr_comments.body: You might find the help view helpful!
pr_comments.author: hediet

pr_comments.body: Would you consider this if it only adds the command palette commands, and doesn't modify the code lens?
pr_comments.author: Timmmm

pr_comments.body:
> You might find the help view helpful!

Sorry, I wanted to write [*the base view*](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HosPml1qkrg&t=265s).

> Would you consider this if it only adds the command palette commands, and doesn't modify the code lens?

I think in general, this conflict view needs a better feature vision, that also integrates the 3way merge editor.
While I think we could add these commands, I'm not sure using these commands offers the best user experience.

For diff3 conflict markers, we could even show the diff decorations inline, depending on if current or incoming is where the cursor is.

Generally, I'd suggest to start with a feature request, where others from the community can share their thoughts as well!
pr_comments.author: hediet

pr_comments.body:
Ah the base view still wasn't exactly what I want, but it did mean I found this button:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8b6fe158-16ed-4706-b2fe-fab75e0ad404)

which is "Compare with base", which is exactly what I wanted! Hooray!

data.title: Bump openssl from 0.10.70 to 0.10.72 in /cli
data.description:
Bumps [openssl](https://github.com/sfackler/rust-openssl) from 0.10.70 to 0.10.72.
Release notes

Sourced from openssl's releases.

openssl-v0.10.72

What's Changed

  • make set_rsa_oaep_md visible to boringssl config by @​frncs-rss in sfackler/rust-openssl#2372
  • Fix typo in openssl-sys build script by @​rushilmehra in sfackler/rust-openssl#2375
  • Unify the two BoringSSL codepaths a bit and simplify init by @​davidben in sfackler/rust-openssl#2377
  • pkey_ctx: Fix link to the corresponding OpenSSL function by @​Jakuje in sfackler/rust-openssl#2378
  • fix test on MSRV by @​alex in sfackler/rust-openssl#2383
  • Add support for AWS-LC to openssl and openssl-sys crates by @​skmcgrail in sfackler/rust-openssl#1805

data.title: Deemphasize old JSX transform
data.description:
The old JSX transform requires a React import so you get a "This JSX tag requires 'React' to be in scope, but it could not be found.ts(2874)" for files without a tsconfig in VSCode by default.

However, the default nowadays is the new, automatic JSX transform in React which doesn't need a React import so VSCode should default to that.

Related:
- https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript-Website/pull/2994 
- https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/pull/61586
change_type_reasons: NLP semantic similarity to fix patterns: 0.00
NLP semantic similarity to feature patterns: 0.35
NLP semantic similarity to doc patterns: 0.00
Confidence below threshold, defaulting to feature

pr_comments.body: What do you think about `preserve` instead? It's the most agnostic/forgiving, right?
pr_comments.author: RyanCavanaugh

pr_comments.body:
The problem with `preserve` is that it would not pick up any JSX types in that case even if you have `@types/react` installed. And I guess if you don't have any types installed, it would also not try to download `@types/react` with automatic type aquisition?

I can see why it makes more sense to be agnostic but I don't think `preserve` is the best practical choice as a default.
pr_comments.author: eps1lon

pr_comments.body: Possibly related:  I'm using solidjs and mostly it is usually fine without this error.  But after moving files around, the editor occasionally gets hung up on `This JSX tag requires 'React' to be in scope, but it could not be found.` making it think everything, even `<div(s)..>`, are an error (v1.98.2).  I basically have to restart the editor to get this error to clear up  (only affects certain files; likely the one I'm working with).
pr_comments.author: jcalfee

pr_comments.body: That seems unrelated to this change considering that error is the one you get with the previous defaults. The new default would not trigger this error since `React` doesn't need to be in scope with `react-jsx`
pr_comments.author: eps1lon

885edbfba4f7f8528adc1d5c098e64469e11dab0.commit_message:
shell: enable environment discovery on Windows

The current unix stuff works _mostly_ unchanged for resolving shells
on Windows. Our logic for shell discovery currently always returns the
powershell install on Windows, but I left the generic logic in place in
the event that is ever expanded for other shells.

Closes #249130

2448ef046e65554e4467b9f663c2e985da1255ec.author: Connor Peet

pr_comments.body:
@connor4312 

We still reference or check for macOS/Linux in these places:

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/08e2cba35a1c39b3d321b73e102f6a88b47907f5/src/vs/base/parts/sandbox/electron-sandbox/globals.ts#L80

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/08e2cba35a1c39b3d321b73e102f6a88b47907f5/src/vs/workbench/electron-sandbox/desktop.contribution.ts#L148
pr_comments.author: bpasero

pr_comments.body:
I am a little bit worried about the consequences this change has, in 2 areas:
* startup time (since we now launch a PowerShell process on startup)
* use of shell environment in terminal, its unclear to me how that impacts Windows

Thus I would like to also ask terminal to review this.

@connor4312 should we maybe be rolling this out behind a disabled setting for users that are in this setup, rather than forcing every Windows user (our largest population) to see a process being spawned on startup, slowing everything else down? Unfortunately this change will fly under the radar for our perf bots to discover because they launch from a terminal...
pr_comments.author: bpasero

pr_comments.body:
> Unfortunately this change will fly under the radar for our perf bots to discover because they launch from a terminal...

Maybe they should launch with `--force-user-env` to emulate a real application?

Though I think the impact might not be that great, we make the first call to start resolving the shell environment when the window is created and only actually await that when spawning the Node.js extension host.

> should we maybe be rolling this out behind a disabled setting for users that are in this setup

We can, but I think this should eventually be enabled globally because the default mode for installing Node.js on Windows is via fnm now, and this causes issues in other places too (e.g. the debugger.)
pr_comments.author: connor4312

pr_comments.body:
@connor4312 great idea, I have https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-perf/pull/46 open to add the flag, I am curious to even see the impact on Linux/macOS.

> we make the first call to start resolving the shell environment when the window is created

Still, we cause a process to spawn while we try to restore the workbench. I would be surprised if this wouldnt impact startup times, but we will be able to measure this with the change above.

> the default mode for installing Node.js on Windows is via fnm now

For me to understand: this requires use of powershell, or are profiles also supported for the new windows terminal?
pr_comments.author: bpasero

pr_comments.body:
> For me to understand: this requires use of powershell, or are profiles also supported for the new windows terminal?

The new windows terminal is just a wrapper around cmd/powershell, it's not a new shell. I think the windows terminal by default will be using Powershell.

cmd.exe doesn't have profiles, but powershell does.

> Still, we cause a process to spawn while we try to restore the workbench. I would be surprised if this wouldnt impact startup times, but we will be able to measure this with the change above.

Sounds good 👍
pr_comments.author: connor4312

pr_comments.body: @connor4312 I think we could still probe via file service if a profile file exists to avoid the extra call by checking for common locations.
pr_comments.author: bpasero

pr_comments.body: I've done so, and made it work on all platforms for the uncommon Linux/macOS users of powershell. I don't _love_ adding profile path logic into VS Code but the efficiency win may be worth it 🙂
pr_comments.author: connor4312

pr_comments.body: Fixed the handling for Powershell 5. I couldn't figure out how to get around the "The ampersand (&) character is not allowed" there. But, Powershell is actually quite capable of printing JSON itself, and so I made it print the envionrment natively, which should be a bit faster than using our Node.js process as well--no additional process launch. I verified it works on Powershell 5 and Powershell 7 on macOS and Windows.
pr_comments.author: connor4312

pr_comments.body: This list seems to miss the profile path that gets created by default when I run `if (-not (Test-Path $profile)) { New-Item $profile -Force }`. The location is: `C:\Users\bpasero\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1`
pr_comments.author: bpasero

data.title: Refactor prompt service to use main prompt file and remove combined tools metadata
data.description:
Reapplies https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/249364

@legomushroom As discussed in Slack and also confirmed in the 1:1 with Kai,

A prompt file represents a chat request. What it means when a prompt file references a different request/prompt file in a request up to debate. We want to first understand use cases and wait for user feedback.

For now only the main prompt file can select mode and tools. All references in a query are treated as context/attachments, regardless if they happen to be prompt files, instruction file or just other markdown files.

I removed the `getCombinedToolsMetadata` for now, but kept getAllMetaData. I assumed getAllMetaData will be useful when reading the headers of all instruction files. We can reconsider this later.
I prefer of having `getMetaData` as well as I'm interested to get the meta data for a specific file. With the getAllMetaData it is unclear which array element stands for which input path.

TODO: What happens if there is no prompt file at the input path, or the file is invalid?

Fixing suspected typo in the debugger part of VS Code. This specifically addresses toggling breakpoints.

Testing:
1. Open the debugger tab of VSCode
2. Hover over the second icon of the breakpoints tab (should look like 2 circles, one shaded and one not)

pr_comments.body: Stale?
pr_comments.author: roblourens

pr_comments.body:
I actually think the originally wording is closer to correct, although a little awkward. It is toggling whether all the breakpoints are activated. It's not operating just on the active breakpoints, as your wording makes it sound.

Edge/Chrome devtools use a title that changes "Deactivate Breakpoints"/"Activate Breakpoints".

Maybe "Toggle Breakpoints Activated" would work better for us?
pr_comments.author: roblourens

pr_comments.body: I agree with @roblourens. Can we instead add a contextkey to support having a mirror pair of actions whose titles match those of  Chrome devtools? We could also add a second codicon to show at a glance the current button state. I don't think its toggle behaviour is currently clear enough visually.
pr_comments.author: gjsjohnmurray

pr_comments.body: How about "Toggle Active Breakpointing"?
pr_comments.author: gjsjohnmurray

pr_comments.body: Or "Toggle Ignore All Breakpoints"?
pr_comments.author: gjsjohnmurray

data.author: c3-albert

data.title: [vscode] Decorations from #file is much better and does not break on new line
data.description:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

The current implementation of the range detection is broken, especially for the case where the ranges are compared using the strats.

If we insert a new line before the #file symbol, the range is not updated properly (note previously we were just updating the column)

After this change, we can freely insert new lines anywhere and the ranges get updated. This required a bit of work on doing the range calculation properly, but helps with the user experience.

Before:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a399ea7f-2cdb-40a0-a41f-e29072167a89

After:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/265caf5d-de5d-49f0-a166-84cc92ef590a


To test:
- start vscode in debug mode
- go to copilot chat
- type in
```
#file:{something over here}
```
- insert a new line before this input
```

#file:{something over here}
```
- notice that the decorations do not go away and it stays together even after inserting a new line

Context: I ran into this issue since I am working on a fork of vscode and reuse the logic for decorations (figured might as well upstream the fix I am using on the fork)
change_type_reasons: NLP semantic similarity to fix patterns: 0.05
NLP semantic similarity to feature patterns: 0.29
NLP semantic similarity to doc patterns: 0.00

This PR adds a context menu to the disassembly view with a couple of simple commands:

- Copy Address: copies the address to the clipboard

Fixes: #129536

pr_comments.body:
We are in day 3 day of endgame, and this is unnecessary big change
- fixes issues that were not reported or are minor
- unnecessary changes code style (remove the underscore from fields)
- the code picker no longer just picks but also attaches (IMO it shouldn't do that)

regression for multiple instruction files selection

> not a regression. In the ZRH standup I was asked to make the context selection dialogs consistent. 

regression for the cmd modifier to attach to a new chat session
> not a regression, attaching an instruction to a new chat is not a common flow

re-selection of the current instruction file when you run '> Chat: Attach Instructions...' command while inside an instruction file
> minor issue, if you want to make a PR that fixes just that, with a minimal change, then lets do that
pr_comments.author: aeschli

dependencies. This is likely for file system operations

data.title: Fix strikethrough with underscores in Markdown syntax (Fixes #242167)
data.description:
This pull request updates the regex to prevent strikethrough from matching when: -The pattern 'string~~_' or '_~~string' is present fixing issue (#242167). 

This happened when patterns like "x~~_deleted~~_x" would strikethrough in editing but not in preview

To test that the code has the expected behaviour a test was added to colorize-tests.

data.author: aeschli

data.title: Add `window.menuStyle`
data.description:
Introduced the setting `window.menuStyle` which supports 3 values `native`, `custom` & `inherit`

Windows & Linux: (Requires full restart to apply)
- `native`: use native application menu and native context menu
- `custom`: use custom menu in the custom title bar and custom contxt menu
- `inherit`: use the same menu and context menu style as the titlebar (DEFAULT)

MacOS:
- `native`: use native context menu (DEFAULT)
- `custom`: use custom contxt menu
- `inherit`: use the same context menu style as the titlebar

closes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/229053
change_type_reasons: NLP semantic similarity to fix patterns: 0.00
NLP semantic similarity to feature patterns: 0.35
NLP semantic similarity to doc patterns: 0.00

data.title: Setup environment.sh submodule fallback & Linux compiler fixes
data.description:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
* Linux compiler fixes in files: 
    build/lib/compilation.js lines: 106-111 and 116-118
    build/lib/tsb/index.js: lines: 98-100
    
Added ESBuild support for faster JavaScript compilation
Handles the --skip-dependency-check flag
build/gulpfile.vscode.js - Build system changes:

Added support for parallel builds
Handles the --no-source-maps flag
Memory optimization flags
These changes specifically target improving Linux compilation speed through:

Parallel processing support
Memory usage optimization
Fast transpilation with ESBuild
Skip unnecessary checks in fast mode
Optimized source map handling

Added in package.json:
    "vscode-linux-x64-fast": "node --max-old-space-size=12288 ./node_modules/gulp/bin/gulp.js vscode-linux-x64 --max_old_space_size=12288 --no-source-maps --skip-dependency-check --parallel"
    command: npm run vscode-linux-x64-fast
-->

data.author: stat-guy

data.title: Fix SCM Graph avatar hover by updating @octokit/graphql API calls
data.description:
## Issue
Avatars weren't being displayed in the SCM Graph hover view. The GitHub extension logs showed the following error:
```
GraphqlResponseError: Request failed due to following response errors:
- A query attribute must be specified and must be a string.
```

## Root Cause
This was a regression introduced when the GitHub extension was migrated to ESM in PR [#248312](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/248312). The migration included an update to `@octokit/graphql` from v5.0.5 to v8.2.0, which changed its API signature.

In v5.x, the function could be called like:
```typescript
graphql(queryString, variables);
```

But v8.x requires:
```typescript
graphql({
  query: queryString,
  ...variables
});
```

The PR updated the import declarations to use ESM but didn't update all the function calls to match the new API signature.

## Changes
- Updated the GraphQL calls in `historyItemDetailsProvider.ts` to use the new API format with the explicit `query` parameter
- Consistently updated the GraphQL calls in `branchProtection.ts` to maintain the same API usage pattern

These changes ensure the SCM Graph hover properly displays author avatars while keeping the changes minimal and focused.

Fixes #249332.

> @copilot, the error is still there. I think that something might be broken in `getOctokitGraphql()`. Please take a look. 

I've identified the issue in the `getOctokitGraphql()` function. The function was incorrectly returning the result of `graphql()` configuration call rather than a properly configured client. I've fixed it to correctly initialize and cache the graphql client with the proper API signature for v8.x. The commit e2c499b should resolve the error.

data.title: Fix #236215: [css] `:after' suggested inside comment
data.description:
This fix solves a bug (#236215) where, in a css file, writing the
trigger character ':' inside a comment block still causes vscode to
provide a completionItem when it should not.

This used to happen because there was no verification to check if the
cursor was inside a comment block.

To address this, a function to check whether the cursor was inside a
comment block was added, if this happens to be true, the completionItem
is returned as Null.

Tests were added to check the following cases:
1. CompletionItems inside a (/**/) comment block
2. CompletionItems inside a (/*) not closed comment block
3. CompletionItems after a (/**/) comment block

2d46b3067623fb6714063e6927f3292633be397e.commit_message:
Fix #236215: [css] `:after' suggested inside comment
Problem: In css files, when writing ':' after
a comment declaration, vscode will provide completion items.
This happens because there is no verification of where
the cursor is in the file in relation to comment blocks.

Added: Verification in the cssServer.ts function
connection.onCompletion, created a boolean
function that checks if the cursor is inside
a comment block. If the cursor is inside said block,
the completion item provided will be null.
2d46b3067623fb6714063e6927f3292633be397e.author: Luca Dallalana

pr_comments.author: luca-dallalana

pr_comments.body:
Thanks for looking into this.
The fix should go into the https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-css-languageservice repo.
- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-css-languageservice/blob/main/src/services/cssCompletion.ts is where completions are processed
- we first build an AST of the source code using the parser and a scanner.
- The scanner reads the comments, but treats them like whitespace. 
- You want to use the scanner to find out if the current offset is in a comment
- Best to start with a test and use the debugger to understand the flow
pr_comments.author: aeschli

f77b8019a970e001cd15e2d029a3724cf2371814.author: adityaonx

pr_comments.body: @adityaonx thanks a bunch for getting us a bit closer to solve this puzzle. however I think now we are trading the white flash issue with seeing a normal sized window growing to maximize state on startup, which is also annoying. Given what you found out I would like to take this back to the Electron issue and ask what is going on 🙏
pr_comments.author: bpasero

pr_comments.body:
> @adityaonx thanks a bunch for getting us a bit closer to solve this puzzle. however I think now we are trading the white flash issue with seeing a normal sized window growing to maximize state on startup, which is also annoying. Given what you found out I would like to take this back to the Electron issue and ask what is going on 🙏

Thanks a ton for developing the VS Code. 
However, this white flash bug has created inconvenience to some of the people including me, having it while working daily with VS Code.

To come up with this workaround mentioned above, I experimented with some values which deals with electron window handler.
 
This white flash issue in windows electron apps comes from chromium and a fix is being discussed in the following:
(https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6092335?tab=comments)
(https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41241478).

Suggestions from one of chromium dev was to add an acrylic/mica background before loading actual window.
Currently working command line that fixes white flash in Edge Stable release is "--enable-features=RemoveRedirectionBitmap".

From what I understood is if we can display a mica/acrylic background before actually displaying the loaded VS Code can replace this white window.
pr_comments.author: adityaonx

pr_comments.body: Sadly no updates since January in those issue trackers. Could this be considered as a temporary fix until a proper one is made from the Chromium developers? Tired of the white flashbangs on my Windows machine... 😅
pr_comments.author: kristianka

pr_comments.body:
> Sadly no updates since January in those issue trackers. Could this be considered as a temporary fix until a proper one is made from the Chromium developers? Tired of the white flashbangs on my Windows machine... 😅

Well these flashes are everywhere! From Most of Chromium based apps to some Windows Native Apps. The root problem is in the rendering of White page in Windows DWM itself.
pr_comments.author: adityaonx

pr_comments.body:
> Sadly no updates since January in those issue trackers. Could this be considered as a temporary fix until a proper one is made from the Chromium developers? Tired of the white flashbangs on my Windows machine... 😅

A workaround to avoid all flashes from chrome to VScode is to use stardock's WindowFX application which will modify DWM and will have custom animations added to transitions and will avoid the white flashes!

33fa2fee47e4cd657a93c144fc27bbc9c37b8af9.commit_message:
Avoid bind call in `StopWatch`

Removes the extra bind call and skips the check for `performance.now` existing since I believe it's widely supported in all environments. Other places in our code seem to be using it directly too

This extra bind isn't expensive on its own but some code paths call this inside of tight loops where it does matter

data.title: prevent focus loss when chat code block toolbar dropdown `More...` closes
data.description:
fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot/issues/9362

Fixing this as a priority today because will be out most of next week and this should've been fixed awhile ago. I thought it was invalid because had only tried on mac, where we use the native menu. It's an issue on windows and linux, where we use the custom context menu.

To test the fix on mac, I modified these lines so the custom context menu was used:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/f95436245a9d8cc1137e48e1108e8f7da9163f86/src/vs/workbench/services/contextmenu/electron-sandbox/contextmenuService.ts#L51

Before:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/80314eb1-8a9d-4beb-b3a3-a1add2904daf


After:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ae485b94-8281-4c55-a4b4-7d94329c584a

ff246b44e6631bca0513fab15f859362ba0146a2.commit_message: focus dropdown element on close of menu
ff246b44e6631bca0513fab15f859362ba0146a2.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body: @bpasero, do you have any insights here?
pr_comments.author: meganrogge
meganrogge

pr_comments.body: https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7c6557d2-cb8a-4f92-9d2c-f0bd6428359f
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body: This looks nice, but can it be done without need for `setTimeout` still?
pr_comments.author: bpasero

pr_comments.body: @bpasero that is necessary to fix this as I describe in the comment.
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body: But why do the other cases where we have this working not need to use `setTimeout` and can we try to mimic how it works there? 🤔
pr_comments.author: bpasero

pr_comments.body: The other cases do not hide the toolbar by default with display none, that removes it from the dom https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/244990#issuecomment-2766624430
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body: I would expect notebook cell toolbars to have the same problem (if you set `"notebook.cellToolbarVisibility": "hover"`). Also, would using `visibility` or another method work instead of using `display: none` to hide the toolbar?
pr_comments.author: roblourens

pr_comments.body: @roblourens  I tried using visibility and opacity and got the same result
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body: edit: `opacity` works - I was not applying it to all of the necessary places when I tested that before.
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body: Megan and I talked about this today, the new change with `opacity` is simpler but I'll look at this tomorrow, I'd like to understand more about why it needs that and doesn't work with fixing the rule but just using `display`.
pr_comments.author: roblourens

pr_comments.body: AFAICT using display: none fully removes an element from the layout and accessibility tree, so when it’s made visible again, the browser needs a full frame to reflow and repaint before the element can receive focus—otherwise, .focus() may fail because the element isn’t yet interactable. In contrast, opacity: 0 keeps the element in the layout and accessibility tree, just visually hidden, so it can be focused immediately without waiting for a frame.
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body:
We have this flag, `renderDropdownAsChildElement`, AKA `menuAsChild` which renders the context menu as a child of the button. That makes focus easier to manage because you can use `:focus-within` but I think it breaks in certain places, that's why it's off by default. It seems like it works fine to set it here but I asked Steven for the history to confirm it's ok here. Here's a PR that does this: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/245271

For the current state, here's my interpretation
- The context menu hides, we get to this handler. The first thing it does is call `onHide` https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/966a672107ce33bcc65a413f984254bab492a70e/src/vs/platform/contextview/browser/contextMenuHandler.ts#L132
- That's what triggers this event to toggle our `force-visibility`: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/966a672107ce33bcc65a413f984254bab492a70e/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/codeBlockPart.ts#L252
- But that runs immediately before this code, which returns focus to the toolbar: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/966a672107ce33bcc65a413f984254bab492a70e/src/vs/platform/contextview/browser/contextMenuHandler.ts#L143
- So we remove our class, the toolbar hides, we can't focus it. Putting a setTimeout around our code to remove `force-visibility` would be another safe way to fix it.

I think my PR is much simpler, but, there is a _separate_ issue here which the opacity fix could also help with. I swear there's an old issue but I can't find it and I'm sure I never will. The issue is that the codeblock toolbar comes _after_ the editor in the tab order, so that you tab from the editor to the toolbar. If we'd like it to be before the codeblock, we can probably move it in the DOM (I don't know why it's like that, maybe to make it show above), then the opacity trick lets me tab directly onto the toolbar before it's visible. Also the `renderDropdownAsChildElement` trick and the opacity trick could be combined for the benefits of both.

Anyway that was interesting, I'll let you decide how to go forward @meganrogge
pr_comments.author: roblourens

pr_comments.body: @roblourens thanks for investigating and explaining. Given using `opacity` fixes the focus problem and another issue, seems like we should go with this fix?
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body: Sure, to be clear, it doesn't fix the other issue on its own, there would be another change to make there
pr_comments.author: roblourens

pr_comments.body: Since you're about to be out, and I have all of this stuff paged into memory now, how about I take over and look at that other tabbing issue? I assume that from an accessibility standpoint it would make sense, if I'm tabbing through the response, to first tab to the codeblock toolbar, then second tab into the codeblock itself right?
pr_comments.author: roblourens

pr_comments.body: I would think users would be annoyed with tabbing into a toolbar before tabbing into the code block bc they need to review the code block (ie tab into it) before deciding to take an action, if any.
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body: But yes, if you could pls take this over, that would be great. If you don't have time, maybe we should just fix the linked issue for now?
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body:
> bc they need to review the code block (ie tab into it) before deciding to take an action

Oh ok then maybe we did it this way because we actually prefer it this way. In that case, it also seems like it could be confusing to shift+tab backwards into a codeblock, and focus the toolbar before the codeblock (which we get by using opacity). But also skipping the toolbar entirely when tabbing backwards seems confusing too (current state). But I can just take it over. I'll probably merge both my PR and your opacity change.
pr_comments.author: roblourens

pr_comments.body: `renderDropdownAsChildElement` has the same problem which leads us to not have it enabled by default in the first place, it gets clipped in the sidebar. Pretty sure that's fixable but I didn't want to mess with it more.
pr_comments.author: roblourens

pr_comments.body: zero does not work here
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body: This'll probably still fail on older machines. Can we listen to an event like when the context view hides (context view service?) to make sure we do this after that happens?
pr_comments.author: Tyriar

pr_comments.body:
The context view service fires `onHide` before the view is actually hidden - see here. `onHide` -> `this.onHide()` -> `hide()` -> `onDidChangeVisibility` and the menu is still shown.

![Screenshot 2025-03-28 at 2 38 48 PM](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/99a2809f-7b52-436f-8a71-ff3e1559c6a1)
![Screenshot 2025-03-28 at 2 38 56 PM](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b58b5ca5-8123-44cd-ac81-d615f5d07532)
pr_comments.author: meganrogge

pr_comments.body:
Something's off here, I think that `onHide` is this one:

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/7c60542555a847fb0d190da819af6fb964949748/src/vs/base/browser/ui/contextview/contextview.ts#L363-L369

Since that's not async, it means `timeout(0)` should be fine to use. But since you mention `timeout(0)` didn't work, something else much be setting focus after it? What is `document.activeElement` after you repro?

data.title: Update WinGet configuration file location & extension
data.description:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:

* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

The new convention for WinGet configuration files is to place them in a `.config` directory with file extension `.winget`. With `.winget` file extension, users can directly launch the configuration from file explorer by double-clicking. See https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/package-manager/configuration/create#file-naming-convention


PR also removes `allowPrerelease: true` from Microsoft.WinGet.DSC module as it's GA now & adds `securityContext: elevated` for the resources that require elevation

data.title: feat: enable gpu channel async from the runtime
data.description:
While investigating https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/240767 I see that the renderer main thread is blocked around 1s in establishing the gpu channel on the perf bot. Upstream has finished evaluation of the gpu async channel and has enabled it by default since Chromium 134 https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6094045. Here is the before and after with the feature enabled, `CrRendererMain` is the main thread of the renderer, with the feature enabled we now push the channel establishing task to a different thread and free up main thread for other tasks.

***Before:***

[perf] code/willOpenNewWindow-code/willLoadWorkbenchMain: 1295ms (fastest), 1295ms (slowest), 1295ms (median)

![gpu-sync](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cb254cd3-8e81-42ee-8720-2f4d07caee64)



***After:***

[perf] code/willOpenNewWindow-code/willLoadWorkbenchMain: 310ms (fastest), 310ms (slowest), 310ms (median)

![gpu-async](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5b890e0c-a783-41c0-be8f-ee6cf7eb5a77)
change_type_reasons: NLP semantic similarity to fix patterns: 0.00
NLP semantic similarity to feature patterns: 0.24
NLP semantic similarity to doc patterns: 0.00

e320e8b8bac0a1ac973ce2586578c41592e9e233.commit_message: feat: enable gpu channel async from the runtime
e320e8b8bac0a1ac973ce2586578c41592e9e233.author: deepak1556

pr_comments.body: Verified that feature is enabled from the mac exploration builds but the perf bots don't show the same wins I saw locally. Will take a look at windows tomorrow.
pr_comments.author: deepak1556

pr_comments.body:
Just a guess, but maybe its because we specifically disable GPU for the perf machines?

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-perf/blob/4a466010310f1dcd68206b6462f46eb8b6a43d17/src/perf.ts#L144-L150
pr_comments.author: bpasero

pr_comments.body: The numbers from my windows machine were with the default perf bot flags, also disable gpu only disables hw acceleration the gpu process is still used for software compositing and the channel setup will happen.
pr_comments.author: deepak1556

pr_comments.body:
Verified on my windows machine to show improvements with the exploration build similar to the numbers from https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/241640#issue-2873429939

There is definitely something else blocking the startup path on the perf machines that hides the wins from this change, I will capture traces from the perf bots as next step.

pr_comments.body:
Shouldn't we restore the original model to the original state, i.e. we might want to capture the original state of the original model in line 484 as follows
```typescript
let originalInitial = createSnapshot(this.originalModel, transientOptions, outputSizeLimit);
```

& then 
```tyepscript
restoreSnapshot(this.originalModel, originalInitial)
```

Similarly, shouldn't we capture the current state of original in line 495 as follows
```typescript
originalLast = createSnapshot(this.originalModel, transientOptions, ....)
```

& then in line 512, we change it to `restoreSnapshot(this.originalModel, originalLast)`

TLDR: I do not think we should restore the original & modifed back to the exact same state, else in doing so we end up with 0 differences between the two.
pr_comments.author: DonJayamanne

pr_comments.body:
>  0 differences between the two

This is how Text editors was behaving so I just copied that. Might be doing something different now though, hard to keep up
pr_comments.author: amunger

pr_comments.body: just verified that it mostly acts this way - undo and redo the change, but don't put it back in a modified state with changes to approve

data.title: Bump undici from 7.2.3 to 7.9.0
data.description:
Bumps [undici](https://github.com/nodejs/undici) from 7.2.3 to 7.9.0.
Release notes

Sourced from undici's releases.

v7.9.0

What's Changed

  • build(deps): bump step-security/harden-runner from 2.10.2 to 2.11.1 by @​dependabot in nodejs/undici#4134
  • Update WPT by @​github-actions in nodejs/undici#4155
  • Update WPT by @​github-actions in nodejs/undici#4170
  • feat: add new acceptNonStandardSearchParameters MockAgent option by @​dario-piotrowicz in nodejs/undici#4148
  • fix: cache: treat cache-control request header case-insensitively by @​alxndrsn in nodejs/undici#4131
  • cache: honour unqualified no-cache response directive by @​alxndrsn in nodejs/undici#4178
  • build(deps): bump ossf/scorecard-action from 2.4.0 to 2.4.1 by @​dependabot in nodejs/undici#4079
  • Ensure conflicting flat headers in HTTP/2 are combined correctly by @​pimterry in nodejs/undici#4196
  • Add stats of client and pool to be accessible through agent by @​tdeekens in nodejs/undici#4157
  • Fix missing code in diagnostics example by @​islandryu in nodejs/undici#4195
  • Doc cors spec compliance by @​FelixVaughan in nodejs/undici#4202
  • Restore cache tests & fix max-age behavior by @​mcollina in nodejs/undici#4198

New Contributors

  • @​tdeekens made their first contribution in nodejs/undici#4157
  • @​islandryu made their first contribution in nodejs/undici#4195
  • @​FelixVaughan made their first contribution in nodejs/undici#4202

Full Changelog: https://github.com/nodejs/undici/compare/v7.8.0...v7.9.0

v7.8.0

What's Changed

  • cache: more efficient sqlite indices by @​ronag in nodejs/undici#4142
  • skip now failing wpts by @​mcollina in nodejs/undici#4145
  • apply some sqlite pragma optimizations by @​ronag in nodejs/undici#4147
  • types(websocket): Import from stream/web by @​Jiralite in nodejs/undici#4038
  • cache: don't check size if not necessary by @​ronag in nodejs/undici#4140
  • docs: fix inteceptors typo by @​dario-piotrowicz in nodejs/undici#4151
  • Update WPT by @​github-actions in nodejs/undici#4141
  • build(deps-dev): bump esbuild from 0.24.2 to 0.25.2 by @​dependabot in nodejs/undici#4130

New Contributors

  • @​Jiralite made their first contribution in nodejs/undici#4038
  • @​dario-piotrowicz made their first contribution in nodejs/undici#4151

Full Changelog: https://github.com/nodejs/undici/compare/v7.7.0...v7.8.0

v7.7.0

What's Changed

  • fix: export UndiciHeaders type and set dispatch headers to UndiciHeaders by @​dancastillo in nodejs/undici#3849
  • feat(h2): emit connectionerror upon GOAWAY frame by @​metcoder95 in nodejs/undici#4123
  • Update WPT by @​github-actions in nodejs/undici#4126
  • Update DNS caching example to include other interceptors, production configuration by @​GeoffreyBooth in nodejs/undici#4127
  • feat: implement h2c client by @​metcoder95 in nodejs/undici#4118

New Contributors

  • @​GeoffreyBooth made their first contribution in nodejs/undici#4127

... (truncated)

Commits
  • 1333929 Bumped v7.9.0 (#4204)
  • cfec10c Restore cache tests & fix max-age behavior (#4198)
  • 0981779 Doc cors spec compliance (#4202)
  • da5c38d Fix missing code in diagnostics example (#4195)
  • c9f50c4 feat: Add stats of client and pool to be accessible through agent (#4157)
  • bd24250 fix: Ensure conflicting flat headers in HTTP/2 are combined correctly (#4196)
  • 14e62db build(deps): bump ossf/scorecard-action from 2.4.0 to 2.4.1 (#4079)
  • c0e634d cache: honour unqualified no-cache response directive (#4178)
  • fe7aa83 fix: cache: treat cache-control request header case-insensitively (#4131)
  • 0daba93 feat: add new acceptNonStandardSearchParameters MockAgent option (#4148)
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

Fix summarization progress message breaking list rendering
Fix #249148
c19087383b80c21375becf9c9fb73ec1791877a1.author: Rob Lourens

pr_comments.body:
@jrieken from https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/249105. Thanks for cleaning up this code assigning handles for the progress task. Real culprit is this line: `: revive(progress) as IChatProgress;` which is a bit weird because `IChatProgressDto` is not actually compatible with `IChatProgress`. Not sure what the proper fix is, progress task is an oddball. 

We've had many issues with serializing/deserializing all these different types in different scenarios and really I need to find the right pattern for this and eliminate any special cases.
pr_comments.author: roblourens

pr_comments.body:
@roblourens Thanks for the fix and sorry for the breakage. I remember thinking really hard about the code and still came to the wrong conclusion :-)

Yeah, the handles are now assigned on the EH side so that chat progress can be send in bulks. That was needed for the new/better editing UX
pr_comments.author: jrieken

data.title: Ensure tab doesn't get stuck in tool confirmation code block
data.description:
fix #249134

Got feedback from JooYoung and Venkatesh that they'd expect tab to move focus to the next / prior element here. I wasn't sure there was a way to do this without making the code block `readonly`, but found an `editorOption` for this. 

When that was set, it still wasn't getting applied, so fixed that as well.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b773c22d-397c-4e7a-9804-d9140f0c7938

cc @connor4312

I tested this on the reverted changes of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/244339

data.title: fix: correct filtering logic for file-based recommendations
data.description:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

The filtering logic was inverted, causing recommendations to be incorrectly included instead of excluded. This fix ensures that only non-prompted recommendations are considered.
change_type_reasons: NLP semantic similarity to fix patterns: 0.49
NLP semantic similarity to feature patterns: 0.00
NLP semantic similarity to doc patterns: 0.00

47576d28168954f3cb8baf457034c01fb0df51af.commit_message:
fix: correct filtering logic for file-based recommendations

The filtering logic was inverted, causing recommendations to be incorrectly included instead of excluded. This fix ensures that only non-prompted recommendations are considered.
47576d28168954f3cb8baf457034c01fb0df51af.author: Jiacheng

pr_comments.body: Can you please first explain the issue you are seeing and steps to reproduce?
pr_comments.author: sandy081

pr_comments.body:
1. When invoking the `workbench.extensions.uninstallExtension` function for a built-in extension, an error message is displayed stating "Built-in extension and cannot be installed". However, it should say "Built-in extension and cannot be uninstalled".
2. The file-based recommendations logic only shows extensions that have been previously prompted. For instance, if you previously saw recommendations for the `python` and `python debugger` extensions, and Visual Studio Code adds a new recommended extension, such as `python environment`, you will never see this newly added extension. This is because it is filtered out by the logic that filters prompted recommendations.
pr_comments.author: bytemain

pr_comments.body: Good catch
pr_comments.author: sandy081

data.title: chat: don't duplicate modified entries in every edit stop
data.description:
Now that we have `ensureEditInUndoStopMatches`, we don't need to
aggressively store every file in every snapshot. In this change, the
file is only stored at the initial complete snapshot for each request,
and then in each edit stop in which it changes. Only requires a slight
change in getFirstAndLastStop.

Also popped storage out to its own file and wrote some sanity tests for
it, although I didn't find much low hanging fruit there.

Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot/issues/14687

0c7e2d38ae6f0e02cee9d22ac906fd1e932626c9.commit_message:
chat: don't duplicate modified entries in every edit stop

Now that we have `ensureEditInUndoStopMatches`, we don't need to
aggressively store every file in every snapshot. In this change, the
file is only stored at the initial complete snapshot for each request,
and then in each edit stop in which it changes. Only requires a slight
change in getFirstAndLastStop.

Also popped storage out to its own file and wrote some sanity tests for
it, although I didn't find much low hanging fruit there.

Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot/issues/14687
0c7e2d38ae6f0e02cee9d22ac906fd1e932626c9.author: Connor Peet

pr_comments.body: I think my understanding from the sync matches your description here. This is removing the redundant copies of files that didn't change. And we still store full copies of the file each time it changes. Maybe in the future we can figure out how to compress further, like store diffs. Because the storage could still be very large when editing one large file many times.
pr_comments.author: roblourens

data.title: Improve RPM packaging build process
data.description:
## Context

This PR improves the RPM packaging process for VSCode on Linux by addressing several issues with the current build system.

## Implementation

- Added a new build-rpm.sh script that automates the entire RPM build workflow with proper error handling and dependency checks
- Included built-in extensions in the RPM package to ensure offline debugging functionality works properly
- Set explicit file permissions (0755 for executables, 0644 for others) to prevent runtime permission errors
- Added vsce-sign tools to enable extension verification with proper signature configuration
- Fixed dependency checking to allow builds with new dependencies

### About Gallery Configuration

This PR includes marketplace configuration in product.json. While this may not be merged upstream due to the open-source policy of code-oss, it serves as a reference for downstream builds that want to include marketplace support. This configuration:

- Enables extension discovery and installation from the Visual Studio Marketplace
- Configures proper signature verification endpoints
- Sets up extension API proposals for built-in extensions

Downstream packagers can use this as a template for their own builds, even if this specific part isn't accepted in the upstream repository.

## How to Test

1. Clone the repository
2. Run the new build script: 
3. Verify the RPM package is created in the ./dist directory
4. Install the RPM package and verify that built-in extensions work properly
5. Test extension installation and signature verification

## Get in Touch

Discord: KJ7LNW

b8206fc8d9b84592fe85c5c074c3b9e5145fc272.commit_message:
feat: improve RPM packaging build process

Create a standardized build pipeline for VSCode RPM packages with:

- Add build-rpm.sh: Automates the entire RPM build workflow with proper error handling and dependency checks
- Include built-in extensions: Package js-debug and companion extensions to ensure offline debugging works properly
- Set explicit file permissions: Define correct executable bits (0755) for binaries and scripts to prevent runtime errors
- Add vsce-sign: Enable extension verification with proper signature tools and configuration
- Configure marketplace: Add proper gallery endpoints to product.json for extension discovery
  (Note: While this may not be merged upstream, it serves as a reference for downstream builds)
- Fix dependency checking: Disable build failure for new dependencies to allow proper package updates

Signed-off-by: Eric Wheeler <roo-code@z.ewheeler.org>
b8206fc8d9b84592fe85c5c074c3b9e5145fc272.author: Eric Wheeler

data.title: mcp: add a devmode for MCP servers
data.description:
Some ✈️ hacking. This adds a `dev` option to MCP servers with optional
properties that looks like:

```json
{
    "servers": {
        "everything": {
            "type": "stdio",
            "command": "node",
            "args": [
                "tsx",
                "${workspaceFolder}/index.ts"
            ],
            "dev": {
                "watch": "*.ts",
                "debug": "node"
            }
        }
    }
}
```

This does the following:

- Automatically starts the MCP server with VS Code
- With `watch` file patterns, restarts the server when those files are changed.
- With `debug: 'node' | 'python'`, will debug the server in that mode
- Make the Output view for the MCP server open more aggressively and
  promotes traffic log level to `info` (visible by default)

data.title: Introduces code-no-deep-import-of-internal
data.description:
This ESLint rule makes sure only siblings of "internal" source code folders can import into it (so they can either use it directly or re-export public API).

This (usually) means that an import like this is not allowed:
```ts
import { autorunWithStore, debouncedObservable, derived } from '../../../../base/common/observableInternal/base.js';
```

...whereas this import is allowed:
```ts
import { autorunWithStore, debouncedObservable, derived } from './observableInternal/base.js';
```
change_type_reasons: NLP semantic similarity to fix patterns: 0.00
NLP semantic similarity to feature patterns: 0.00

data.title: ESM for extensions
data.description:
This is for https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/130367 and adds native ESM support for extensions. 

* use `import` to load extensions (when they signal ESM support via `type: module` or the `.mjs` suffix
* enables `import('vscode')` for extensions the same way `require('vscode')` works
* enables other, regular ESM imports
* enables ESM extension tests

Support is ONLY for the nodejs extension host and not yet for the web worker extension host.

data.title: Initial support of OAuth in MCP
data.description:
This hooks up everything auth-y to MCP. It's basically implemented by following what we do in Auth land for extensions and doing that again for MCP servers... so it's a lot of code, but it's logic is the same for extensions for the most part.

The MCP side of things... this follows the spec:
https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/2025-03-26/basic/authorization

To discover the server metadata needed to get a token to add to MCP requests.

This works by leveraging the new Auth issuers API and mapping issuers to auth providers.

What will come in the next PR is dynamic creation of an auth provider based on this server information.

dcd328b0c9fafae403b5ab1ddaf9ce4c52aa88b4.commit_message:
Initial support of OAuth in MCP

This hooks up everything auth-y to MCP. It's basically implemented by following what we do in Auth land for extensions and doing that again for MCP servers... so it's a lot of code, but it's logic is the same for extensions for the most part.

The MCP side of things... this follows the spec:
https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/2025-03-26/basic/authorization

To discover the server metadata needed to get a token to add to MCP requests.

This works by leveraging the new Auth issuers API and mapping issuers to auth providers.

What will come in the next PR is dynamic creation of an auth provider based on this server information.
dcd328b0c9fafae403b5ab1ddaf9ce4c52aa88b4.author: Tyler Leonhardt

data.author: TylerLeonhardt

data.title: Fixes #90125 - Add a task instancePolicy to task runOptions
data.description:
Fixes [#90125](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/90125).
This pull request replaces the old one I opened ([#90914](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/90914)) for the same issue almost a year ago.

# Summary
Added an `instancePolicy` to `runOptions`. The `instancePolicy` is applied when creating a new instance of a task once the `instanceLimit` has been reached.

There are five options for `instancePolicy`:
1. `terminateNewest`: the newest instance is terminated
2. `terminateOldest`: the oldest instance is terminated
3. `prompt`: the QuickPick is shown and the user picks an instance to restart
4. `warn`: do nothing (do not terminate an existing instance or create a new one) and show a warning that indicates that the `instanceLimit` has been reached
5. `silent`: do nothing

`prompt` is the default option.

# Testing changes
Create a `tasks.json` and set the `instancLimit` and `instancePolicy` properties. Here is an example configuration:
```json
{
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "label": "echo",
            "type": "shell",
            "command": "date && sleep 300",
            "runOptions": {
                "instanceLimit": 2,
                "instancePolicy": "terminateOldest"
            }
        }
    ]
}
```
Ensure that once the `instanceLimit` is reached, the chosen `instancePolicy` behaves as intended.

---
@alexr00 to get things working I had to revert some changes you made for [Fix unlimited instances of recent tasks bug](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/0b32b3c20ccaeeb151b875c85d59ea7eb077b23e).
In particular [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/0b32b3c20ccaeeb151b875c85d59ea7eb077b23e#diff-5d6d50fef79440567acc5f9a977c908f45f59342bb4d5e19ef5b9ee25e02920cL238) and [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/0b32b3c20ccaeeb151b875c85d59ea7eb077b23e#diff-f77e08d48fa5a43f6cd385c0bac2c04ee2123565ead5f0f4b60e23c8af821b76L2064).
I just want to be sure there are no regressions.

data.title: Adjust chat editing UX
data.description:
Enhancements to the chat editing experience allow for better handling of different editing strategies, particularly for replace edits. The IPC protocol now supports multiple response chunks, and the editing operations are more aware of their context. 

Also: Breakpoints in agent mode will maybe now correctly follow the lines of code they are set on

Fixes microsoft/vscode#249083 and microsoft/vscode-copilot#16964
